qas.question: What author had a great impact in Rome?
Who was able to spread the idea of equality among all through his words?
From where did this school of thought emerge?
Who again issued the same type of challenge centuries later
What was the name of the main belief Terence offered
What author had little impact in Rome?
Who was able to spread the idea of equality among all without any words?
What was the name of the main belief Terence avoided?
Where was no school of thought taken seriously?

context: The words of the comic playwright <a0_0><b5_0>P. Terentius Afer<b5_0/><a0_0/> reverberated across the Roman world of the mid-2nd century BCE and beyond. <a1_0><b6_0>Terence<b6_0/><a1_0/>, an African and a former slave, was well placed to preach the message of <a4_0><b7_0>universalism<b7_0/><a4_0/>, of the essential unity of the human race, that had come down in philosophical form from <a2_0>the <b8_0>Greeks<b8_0/><a2_0/>, but needed the pragmatic muscles of Rome in order to become a practical reality. The influence of Terence's felicitous phrase on Roman thinking about human rights can hardly be overestimated. Two hundred years later <a3_0>Seneca<a3_0/> ended his seminal exposition of the unity of humankind with a clarion-call:
